conclusion: Introduction to the problem with block A and cylinder B on inclined planes.
Description of the initial scenario with block A resting on a 37-degree incline.
Block A is on a 37-degree incline with forces in equilibrium.
Weight of block A resolved into components: parallel (Mg sin(37°)) and perpendicular (Mg cos(37°)).
Normal force N equals Mg cos(37°).
Friction force f equals Mg sin(37°).
Static friction force f equals μs N, leading to μs = tan(37°) = 0.75.
Introduction to the second scenario with a 30-degree incline and cylinder B.
Weight of A is 4mg, normal force from incline on A is N', and friction force is f'.
Cylinder B is smooth, implying no friction between B and the incline.
Free-body diagram for A includes weight Mg, normal force N', friction force f', and force from B.
Weight of B is mg, acting downward.
Normal force from incline on B is N_b = mg cos(30°).
Force exerted by B on A is the normal force due to B's weight.
Components of B's weight: parallel (mg sin(30°)) and perpendicular (mg cos(30°)).
Net force on B should be zero due to no friction.
